original.problem:
XXXIX OM - III - Problem 4

Let $ d $ be a positive integer, and $ f \: \langle 0; d\rangle \to \mathbb{R} $ a continuous function such that $ f(0) = f(d) $. Prove that there exists $ x \in \langle 0; d-1\rangle $ such that $ f(x) = -f(x + 1) $.
original.solution:
We consider the function $ g(x) = f(x+1)-f(x) $ defined and continuous in the interval $ \langle 0; d-1 \rangle $. The sum

of the terms, by assumption, is zero, which means either all its terms are zero, or some two terms are of different signs. In any case, there exist integers $ a, b \in \langle 0; d-1 \rangle $ such that $ g(a) \leq 0 \leq g(b) $. From the continuity of the function $ g $, it follows that there is a point $ x_0 $ in the interval with endpoints $ a $, $ b $ where it takes the value $ 0 $ (Darboux property). The equality $ g(x_0) = 0 $ is equivalent to $ f(x_0) = f(x_0+1) $. We have thus found a point $ x_0 \in \langle 0; d-1 \rangle $, which is what we were looking for in the problem.
Note: It is not difficult to show that the given theorem is not true for any number $ d > 1 $ that is not an integer. It suffices to take any function $ h \colon \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R} $ that is periodic with period $ 1 $, continuous, and such that $ h(0) = 0 $, $ h(d) = d $, and set $ f(x) = h(x)-x $. The function thus defined satisfies the condition $ f(0) = f(d) $, but does not satisfy the equality $ f(x) = f (x +1) $ for any $ x $; such an equality would imply that $ h(x+1) = h(x) + 1 $, which contradicts the periodicity of the function $ h $.

llm_response:
This problem involves proving the existence of a point where a continuous function satisfies a specific relation given certain conditions. The solution employs the continuity of the function and uses the properties of the function defined in the context. 

Since the problem is fundamentally about proving the existence of such a point and relies on a continuity argument, it falls into the category that cannot be trivially verified through execution or computation in a proof-checking language like Lean. 

Thus, I classify this as: 
UNINTERESTING

original.problem:
11.2. On a plane, the graphs of the functions $y=\sin x$ and $y=\tan x$ are drawn, as well as the coordinate axes. How can one construct a straight line using a compass and a ruler that is tangent to the sine graph both above the x-axis $(O x)$ and below (and possibly has other points of intersection)?

(A. Kuznetsov)
original.solution:
Solution. We will look for a tangent passing through the origin. The tangent to the sine graph at the point $\left(x_{0}, \sin x_{0}\right)$ has the equation $y=\left(x-x_{0}\right) \cdot \cos x_{0}+\sin x_{0}$. This line passes through the origin if and only if $0=-x_{0} \cdot \cos x_{0}+\sin x_{0}$, which is equivalent to $\operatorname{tg} x_{0}=x_{0}$.

It remains to construct the point $\left(x_{0}, \sin x_{0}\right)$. For this (using a compass and a ruler), we will construct the bisector of the coordinate angle, i.e., the line $y=x$. We choose its intersection point with the tangent graph: $\left(x_{0}, \operatorname{tg} x_{0}\right), x_{0} \neq 0$. Then, dropping a perpendicular from this point to the x-axis and intersecting this perpendicular with the sine graph, we obtain the point $\left(x_{0}, \sin x_{0}\right)$. The line passing through the origin and the point $\left(x_{0}, \sin x_{0}\right)$ will touch the sine graph at the point $\left(x_{0}, \sin x_{0}\right)$ by the choice of the point $x_{0}$, and also at the point $\left(-x_{0},-\sin x_{0}\right)$ due to symmetry relative to the origin. These points lie on opposite sides of the x-axis, as required.

llm_response:
This problem involves constructing a tangent line to the graph of the sine function that intersects the graph in specific conditions. This includes both geometric construction (using a compass and a ruler) and understanding properties of the sine and tangent functions.

The solution's focus is on constructing a line and identifying specific points where tangency occurs, which involves an argument about where the tangent touches the curve and additional properties of trigonometric functions. original.problem: 7.3. Prove that there will be a morning when all the numbers in the table will change by no more than 0.01.
original.solution:
Solution. Let's look at the sum of the squares of the numbers in the table. When subtracting the average $a=\frac{1}{k} \sum a_{i}$ from the set $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{k}$, for example, the sum of the squares becomes

$\sum\left(a_{i}-a\right)^{2}=\sum a_{i}^{2}+k a^{2}-2 a \sum a_{i}=\sum a_{i}^{2}+k a^{2}-2 k a^{2}=\sum a_{i}^{2}-k a^{2}$, i.e., it decreases by $k a^{2}$. Since the total decrease (over the entire time) cannot exceed a constant - the initial sum of the squares, all decreases, except for a finite number, do not exceed $(0.01)^{2}$, then $a^{2}<(0.01)^{2}$, i.e., all changes are no more than 0.01.

151. Prove that the function $F(z)$ takes the value 1 at some point located between 2 and 3.

The value of $z$ for which $F(z)=1$ will henceforth always be denoted by the letter e. From problem 151, it follows that $2<e<3$.

The number $e$ plays a significant role in mathematics and often appears in various questions that, at first glance, seem unrelated to the definition of the area "under the hyperbola" (see, for example, problems 156-158, 160-161, or 78).
original.solution:
151. Note that by its very definition, the function $F(z)$ is an increasing function: for $z_{2}>z_{1}$, it is obvious that $F\left(z_{2}\right)>F\left(z_{1}\right)$. Since $F(1)=0$ and $F(z)$ changes continuously as $z$ increases and cannot "skip" any value,

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_21_68334347b64402497ba5g-467.jpg?height=477&width=440&top_left_y=645&top_left_x=224)
a)

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_21_68334347b64402497ba5g-467.jpg?height=442&width=444&top_left_y=659&top_left_x=731)

b).

Fig. 144.

to prove the existence of such a number $e$ for which $F(e)=1$, we only need to show that there exist values of $z$ for which $F(z)>1$.

Let's show that $F(3)>1$. For this purpose, we draw the tangent $B^{\prime} C^{\prime}$ to the hyperbola $y=\frac{1}{x}$ at the point $G$ with coordinates $x=2, y=\frac{1}{2}$ (Fig. 144, a). The area of the trapezoid $A B C D$ $(O A=1, \quad O D=3)$ is 1, since its midline $H G=\frac{1}{2}$, and the height $A D=2$. It follows that the area $F(3)$ of the curvilinear trapezoid $A B C D$ is greater than 1, which is what we needed to prove.

Now let's show that $F(2)<1$. This follows from Fig. 144, b: the area of the curvilinear trapezoid $A B G H(O A=1, O H=2)$, equal to $F(2)$, is definitely less than the area of the square $A B G^{\prime} H$, which is 1.

Thus,

$$
F(2)<1<F(3)
$$

from which it follows that

$$
2<e<3
$$

7.44. Prove that a convex polyhedron cannot be covered by three polyhedra homothetic to it with a coefficient $k$, where $0<k<1$.

original.solution: 7.44. Consider a convex polyhedron $M$ and any three polyhedra $M_{1}, M_{2}$, and $M_{3}$, homothetic to it with a coefficient $k$. Let $O_{1}, O_{2}$, and $O_{3}$ be the centers of the corresponding homotheties. It is clear that if $A$ is the point of the polyhedron $M$ farthest from the plane containing the points $O_{1}, O_{2}$, and $O_{3}$, then $A$ does not belong to any of the polyhedra $M_{1}, M_{2}$, and $M_{3}$. This follows from the fact that under a homothety with coefficient $k$ and center $O$, lying in the plane $\Pi$, the greatest distance from the polyhedron to the plane $\Pi$ changes by a factor of $k$.

original.problem:
111. a) Does there exist a sequence that has no feeder?
b) $*$ Does there exist a sequence for which any segment is a feeder?

## § 2. Problems related to the definition of a limit

A number $a$ is called the limit of a sequence $\left\{x_{n}\right\}$ if for any positive number $\varepsilon$ (the Greek letter "epsilon") there exists a number $k$ such that for all terms of the sequence with index $n$ greater than $k$, the inequality (Fig. 16)

$$
\left|x_{n}-a\right|<\varepsilon
$$

holds for all $n>k$.

A) $\left|x_{n}\right|<1$, B) $\left|x_{n}\right|<0.001$,
C) $\left|x_{n}\right|<0.000001$.
original.solution:
111. a) The sequence $1 ; 2 ; 3 ; \ldots$; $n ; \ldots$ does not have any feeders, since in a segment of length $l$ there are no more than $l+1$ terms of the sequence.

b) We will now construct a sequence that contains all rational numbers. Since any segment contains an infinite set of rational numbers, any segment will be a feeder for such a sequence. To construct the required sequence, we will move along the lines of a grid paper as shown in Fig. 42.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_21_683be32ee1eca857285bg-129.jpg?height=483&width=709&top_left_y=870&top_left_x=224)

Each time we pass through a vertex of a cell, we record one term of the sequence. If the cell has coordinates $x, y$ (as seen from the drawing, $x$ and $y$ are integers, and $y>0$), then the corresponding term of the sequence is $\frac{x}{y}$. Thus, we obtain the sequence $\frac{0}{1} ; \frac{1}{1} ; \frac{1}{2} ; \frac{0}{2} ; \frac{-1}{2} ; \frac{-1}{1} ; \frac{-2}{1} ; \frac{-2}{2} ; \frac{-2}{3} ; \ldots$

We will show that our sequence contains all rational numbers. Indeed, every rational number by definition can be written in the form $\frac{p}{q}$, where $p$ and $q$ are integers and $q>0$. When moving along the plane in the described manner, we will eventually reach a point with coordinates $p, q$. The corresponding term of the sequence will be exactly $\frac{p}{q}$.

In fact, each rational number will appear in our sequence an infinite number of times, since a rational number can be represented in an infinite number of ways as $\frac{p}{q}$ (for example, $\frac{2}{3}=\frac{4}{6}=\frac{6}{9}=\frac{8}{12}=\ldots$). However, it is not so easy to explicitly specify the position of each rational number in the sequence. Try, for example, to find the positions of the numbers $1 \frac{1}{3}, -\frac{5}{7}, 10$. What is the 100th term of this sequence?

llm_response:
This problem revolves around demonstrating the existence of certain sequences based on specific properties, such as having feeders and containing segments that are feeders. It requires creative construction to show the existence of these sequences rather than executing a straightforward computation or proving a concrete property based on existing definitions.

Thus, the problem is asking to prove the existence of a sequence without providing a trivial computational verification path. This points to the nature of the problem being more involved than simply calculating a limit or a derivative.

Therefore, it falls into the category of needing an existence proof, which is not trivially verifiable. 

Classification: UNINTERESTING

original.problem: 130. for $\varepsilon>0$ there exists $k$ such that for $n>k\left|x_{n}-a\right|<\varepsilon$.
original.solution:
130. Let a bounded sequence be given. We select from it an infinite monotonic subsequence (see the solution to problem 128). This subsequence is bounded and, by the Bolzano-Weierstrass axiom, has a limit. We will show that this limit is a limit point of the original sequence.

Indeed, any interval centered at this point is a trap for the selected subsequence. Therefore, it contains infinitely many terms of the original sequence, i.e., this interval is a feeder for the original sequence. Our assertion now follows from theorem 118.

original.problem: 19.7. (SRP, 79). Prove that there does not exist a continuous function $f: \mathbf{R} \rightarrow \mathbf{R}$, possessing the following property: the number $f(x)$ is rational for those and only those values of $x \in \mathbf{R}$ for which the number $f(x+1)$ is irrational.
original.solution:
19.7. Let the function $f(x)$ described in the problem exist. Consider the continuous functions

$$
g(x)=f(x+1)-f(x) \text { and } h(x)=f(x+1)+f(x) .
$$

They cannot both be constant, since otherwise the function $f(x)=(h(x)-g(x)) / 2$ would be constant. Suppose, for example, that $h(x)$ is not a constant function, i.e., there exist such values $x_{1}$ and $x_{2}$ for which $h\left(x_{1}\right)<h\left(x_{2}\right)$. Then there exists a rational number $r \in\left[h\left(x_{1}\right) ; h\left(x_{2}\right)\right]$, and by the continuity of the function $h(x)$, there will be a number $x_{0}$ such that $h\left(x_{0}\right)=r$. Thus, $f\left(x_{0}+1\right)+f\left(x_{0}\right)=r$. Therefore, the numbers $f\left(x_{0}+1\right)$ and $f\left(x_{0}\right)$ are either both rational or both irrational. We have reached a contradiction.

llm_response:
The problem presented revolves around proving the non-existence of a continuous function with a specific property regarding rational and irrational values. This requires constructing a logical argument and applying properties of continuity and rationality, rather than executing a straightforward computation or differentiation. Therefore, the classification for this problem is:

UNINTERESTING

Justification: The problem seeks to prove the non-existence of a function with certain properties, which is a general statement that cannot be trivially verified by a compiler as it requires logical reasoning to establish the contradiction.

## Example 1.

$$
\varphi(x)-\lambda \int_{0}^{1}\left(5 x^{2}-3\right) t^{2} \varphi(t) d t=e^{x}
$$
original.solution:
Solution. We have

$$
\varphi(x)=C \lambda\left(5 x^{2}-3\right)+e^{x}
$$

and

$$
C=\int_{0}^{1} t^{2} \varphi(t) d t
$$

Substituting (6) into (7), we get

$$
C=C \lambda \int_{0}^{1}\left(5 t^{4}-3 t^{2}\right) d t+\int_{0}^{1} t^{2} e^{t} d t
$$

from which

$$
C=e-2 \text {. }
$$

This equation has a unique solution for any $\lambda$

$$
\varphi(x)=\lambda(e-2)\left(5 x^{2}-3\right)+e^{x},
$$

and the corresponding homogeneous equation

$$
\varphi(x)-\lambda \int_{0}^{1}\left(5 x^{2}-3\right) t^{2} \varphi(t) d t=0
$$

has the unique zero solution: $\varphi(x) \equiv 0$.

llm_response:
The problem involves solving an integral equation and determining the unique solution based on the parameters involved. The conclusion drawn here depends on the properties of the equation, particularly the uniqueness of the solution and the integration process involved.

This falls under the category where properties are being examined rather than simply executing a computation or differentiation.

Thus, the classification is: 

UNINTERESTING

original.problem:
## Example 2.

$$
\varphi(x)-\lambda \int_{0}^{1} \sin \ln x \varphi(t) d t=2 x
$$
original.solution:
## Solution. We have

$$
\varphi(x)=C \lambda \sin \ln x+2 x
$$

where $C=\int_{0}^{1} \varphi(t) d t$. Substituting the expression $\varphi(t)$ into the integral, we find

$$
C=C \lambda \int_{0}^{1} \sin \ln t d t+1
$$

from which

$$
C\left(1+\frac{\lambda}{2}\right)=1
$$

If $\lambda \neq-2$, then the given equation has a unique solution

$$
\varphi(x)=\frac{2 \lambda}{2+\lambda} \sin \ln x+2 x
$$

the corresponding homogeneous equation

$$
\varphi(x)-\lambda \int_{0}^{1} \sin \ln x \varphi(t) d t=0
$$

has only the zero solution: $\varphi(x) \equiv 0$.

If, however, $\lambda=-2$, then the given equation has no solutions, since the right-hand side $f(x)=2 x$ is not orthogonal to the function $\sin \ln x$; the homogeneous equation has an infinite number of solutions, since from the equation for determining $C$ ( $0 \cdot C=0$ ) it follows that $C$ is an arbitrary constant; all these solutions are given by the formula

$$
\varphi(x)=\tilde{C} \sin \ln x \quad(\tilde{C}=-2 C)
$$

llm_response:
This problem involves proving existence and uniqueness for a solution to an integral equation, based on the parameter \(\lambda\). The solution requires analyzing conditions under which the equation holds. It also includes reasoning about the orthogonality of functions, leading to characterizing the solutions based on the value of \(\lambda\). Since this involves a deeper understanding of functional properties rather than straightforward computation or differentiation, we can't easily verify such assertions with a lean code compiler.

original.problem:
## Example 2. Solve the equation

$$
\varphi(x)-\lambda \int_{0}^{1} K(x, t) \varphi(t) d t=\cos \pi x
$$

where

$$
K(x, t)= \begin{cases}(x+1) t, & \text { if } \quad 0 \leqslant x \leqslant t \\ (t+1) x, & \text { if } t \leqslant x \leqslant 1\end{cases}
$$
original.solution:
Solution. Characteristic numbers:

$$
\lambda_{0}=1, \quad \lambda_{n}=-n^{2} \pi^{2} \quad(n=1,2, \ldots)
$$

The corresponding eigenfunctions:

$$
\varphi_{0}(x)=e^{x}, \quad \varphi_{n}(x)=\sin n \pi x+n \pi \cos n \pi x \quad(n=1,2, \ldots)
$$

If $\lambda \neq 1$ and $\lambda \neq-n^{2} \pi^{2}$, then the solution of the given equation will have the form

$$
\varphi(x)=\cos \pi x-\lambda\left[\frac{a_{0} e^{x}}{\lambda-1}+\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{a_{n}}{\lambda+n^{2} \pi^{2}}(\sin n \pi x+n \pi \cos n \pi x)\right]
$$

and since

$$
\begin{aligned}
& a_{0}=\int_{0}^{1} e^{x} \cos \pi x d x=-\frac{1+e}{1+\pi^{2}} \\
& a_{n}=\int_{0}^{1} \cos \pi x(\sin n \pi x+n \pi \cos n \pi x) d x= \begin{cases}0, & n \neq 1 \\
\frac{\pi}{2}, & n=1\end{cases}
\end{aligned}
$$

then

$$
\varphi(x)=\cos \pi x+\lambda\left[\frac{1+e}{1+\pi^{2}} \frac{e^{x}}{\lambda-1}-\frac{\pi}{2\left(\lambda+\pi^{2}\right)}(\sin \pi x+\pi \cos \pi x)\right]
$$

When $\lambda=1$ and $\lambda=-\pi^{2}(n=1)$, the equation has no solutions, because its right-hand side, i.e., the function $\cos \pi x$, is not orthogonal to the corresponding eigenfunctions

$$
\varphi_{0}(x)=e^{x}, \quad \varphi_{1}(x)=\sin \pi x+\pi \cos \pi x
$$

If, however, $\lambda=-n^{2} \pi^{2}$, where $n=2,3, \ldots$, then the given equation has an infinite set of solutions, which are given by the formula (6):

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \varphi(x)=\cos \pi x+\lambda\left[\frac{1+e}{1+\pi^{2}} \frac{e^{x}}{\lambda-1}-\frac{\pi}{2\left(\lambda+\pi^{2}\right)}(\sin \pi x+\pi \cos \pi x)\right]+ \\
&+C(\sin n \pi x+n \pi \cos n \pi x)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $C$ is an arbitrary constant.

In some cases, a non-homogeneous symmetric integral equation can be reduced to a non-homogeneous boundary value problem. This can be done when the kernel $K(x, t)$ of the integral equation is the Green's function of some linear differential operator. Let's show on an example how this is done.

original.problem:
Example 1. Solve the integral equation

$$
\varphi(x)=\sin x+2 \int_{0}^{x} \cos (x-t) \varphi(t) d t
$$
original.solution:
Solution. It is known that

$$
\sin x \risingdotseq \frac{1}{p^{2}+1}, \quad \cos x \risingdotseq \frac{p}{p^{2}+1}
$$

Let $\varphi(x) \risingdotseq \Phi(p)$. Applying the Laplace transform to both sides of the equation and using the convolution theorem, we get

$$
\Phi(p)=\frac{1}{p^{2}+1}+\frac{2 p}{p^{2}+1} \Phi(p)
$$

From this,

$$
\Phi(p)\left[1-\frac{2 p}{p^{2}+1}\right]=\frac{1}{p^{2}+1}
$$

or

$$
\Phi(p)=\frac{1}{(p-1)^{2}} \risingdotseq x e^{x}
$$

Therefore, the solution to the integral equation is

$$
\varphi(x)=x e^{x}
$$

## Problems for Independent Solution

Solve the following integral equations:

234. $\varphi(x)=e^{x}-\int_{0}^{x} e^{x-t} \varphi(t) d t . \quad$ 235. $\varphi(x)=x-\int_{0}^{x} e^{x-t} \varphi(t) d t$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_22_d528bb4cd8a42024c50cg-114.jpg?height=125&width=1038&top_left_y=198&top_left_x=47)

238. $\varphi(x)=\cos x-\int_{0}^{x}(x-t) \cos (x-t) \varphi(t) d t$.
239. $\varphi(x)=1+x+\int_{0}^{x} e^{-2(x-t)} \varphi(t) d t . \quad 240 . \varphi(x)=x+\int_{0}^{x} \sin (x-t) \varphi(t) d t$.
240. $\varphi(x)=\sin x+\int_{0}^{x}(x-t) \varphi(t) d t . \quad$ 242. $\varphi(x)=x-\int_{0}^{x} \operatorname{sh}(x-t) \varphi(t) d t$.
241. $\varphi(x)=1-2 x-4 x^{2}+\int_{0}^{x}\left[3+6(x-t)-4(x-t)^{2}\right] \varphi(t) d t$.
242. $\varphi(x)=\operatorname{sh} x-\int_{0}^{x} \operatorname{ch}(x-t) \varphi(t) d t$. 245. $\varphi(x)=1+2 \int_{0}^{x} \cos (x-t) \varphi(t) d t$.
243. $\varphi(x)=e^{x}+2 \int_{0}^{x} \cos (x-t) \varphi(t) d t$. 247. $\varphi(x)=\cos x+\int_{0}^{x} \varphi(t) d t$.

The convolution theorem can also be used to solve nonlinear Volterra integral equations of the form

$$
\varphi(x)=f(x)+\lambda \int_{0}^{x} \varphi(t) \varphi(x-t) d t
$$

Let

$$
\varphi(x) \risingdotseq \Phi(p), \quad f(x) \rightleftharpoons F(p) .
$$

Then, by equation (3),

$$
\Phi(p)=F(p)+\lambda \Phi^{2}(p)
$$

from which

$$
\Phi(p)=\frac{1 \pm \sqrt{1-4 \lambda F(p)}}{2 \lambda}
$$

The original function for $\Phi(p)$, if it exists, will be the solution to the integral equation (3).

original.problem: 364. Prove that a continuous random variable $T$ - the time between the occurrences of two consecutive events in a simple stream with a given intensity $\lambda$ (see Chapter IV, § 2) - has an exponential distribution $F(t)=1-e^{-\lambda t}(t \geqslant 0)$.
original.solution:
Solution. Suppose that at time $t_{0}$, event $A_{i}$ of the flow occurred. Let $t_{1}=t_{0}+t$ (it is recommended to draw a time axis and mark points $t_{0}$ and $t_{1}$ for clarity).

If at least one event of the flow following event $\boldsymbol{A}_{\mathbf{i}}$ occurs within the interval enclosed in the interval ( $t_{0}, t_{1}$ ), for example, in the interval ( $t_{0}, t_{\mathrm{g}}$ ), then the time $T$ between the occurrences of two consecutive events will be less than $t$, i.e., it will be that $T<t$.

To find the probability $P(T<t)$, we should note that the events - "at least one event of the flow appeared within the interval ( $t_{0}, t_{i}$ )" and "no event of the flow appeared within the interval ( $t_{0}, t_{1}$ )" - are opposite (the sum of their probabilities is one).

The probability of no event occurring in the time $t$ is $P_{t}(0)=\frac{\left[(\lambda t)^{0} \cdot \mathrm{e}^{-\lambda t}\right]}{0!}=\mathrm{e}^{-\lambda t}$. Therefore, the probability of the opposite event $P(T<t)=1$ - $\mathrm{e}^{-\lambda t}$, or [by the definition of the distribution function $F(t)=P(T<t)$ ] we have $F(t)=$ $=1-\mathrm{e}^{-\lambda t}$, which is what we needed to prove.

original.problem: 719. Find explicit formulas for simulating a continuous two-dimensional random variable $(X, Y)$, if the component $X$ is given by the probability density function $f_{1}(x) = x / 2$ in the interval $(0; 2)$; the component $Y$ is uniformly distributed in the interval $\left(x_{i}, x_{i}+3\right)$ with density $f_{2}(y)=1 / 3$, where $x_{i}$ is the simulated possible value of $X$.
original.solution:
Solution. We will generate the component $X$ according to rule 2 (§ 3):

$$
\int_{0}^{x_{l}}(x / 2) \mathrm{d} x=r_{i}
$$

From this, we obtain an explicit formula for calculating possible values of $X$:

$$
x_{i}=2 \sqrt{r_{i}}
$$

We will find the conditional distribution function of the component $\gamma$, taking into account that the value $Y$ is uniformly distributed in the interval $\left(x_{i}, x_{i}+3\right)$.

We use rule 1 (§ 3): $\left(y_{i}-x_{i}\right) / 3=r_{i}^{\prime}$, where $r_{i}^{\prime}$ is a random number.

Solving this equation for $y_{i}$, we obtain an explicit formula for calculating possible values of $y$:

$$
y_{i}=3 r_{i}^{\prime}+x_{i}
$$

where $x$ is found using formula (*).

original.problem: 880. Prove that, knowing the spectral density of a differentiable stationary random function, one can find the spectral density of its derivative using the formula $s_{\dot{x}}(\omega)=\omega^{2} s_{x}(\omega)$.
original.solution:
Solution. The derivative of a stationary function is also stationary (see problem 853), therefore the spectral density of the derivative

$$
s_{\dot{x}}(\omega)=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} k_{\dot{x}}(\tau) \mathrm{e}^{-i \omega \tau} \mathrm{d} \tau
$$

Considering that $\boldsymbol{k}_{\dot{x}}(\tau)=-k_{x}^{N}(\tau)$,

$$
k_{x}(\tau)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} s_{x}(\omega) \mathrm{e}^{i \omega \tau} \mathrm{d} \omega
$$

and assuming the validity of differentiating under the integral sign (**) with respect to the parameter $\tau$, we have

$$
k_{\dot{x}}(\tau)=-k_{x}^{\mu}(\tau)=\omega^{2} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} s_{x}(\omega) \mathrm{e}^{i \omega \tau} \mathrm{d} \tau=\omega^{2} k_{x}(\tau)
$$

Substituting (***) into (*), we finally obtain

$$
s_{\dot{x}}(\omega)=\omega^{2} \cdot \frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} k_{x}(\tau) \mathrm{e}^{-i \omega \tau} \mathrm{d} \tau=\omega^{2} s_{x}(\omega)
$$

The problem involves proving a relationship regarding spectral densities related to stationary random functions and their derivatives, which generally requires constructions or assumptions that might not directly translate into a simple verification in a proof assistant language like Lean. Such proofs often depend on various properties of the functions involved and their behaviors, rather than straightforward computations or verifiable statements.

original.problem:
Example 4. Prove that

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{5 x+6}{6 x}=\frac{5}{6}
$$
original.solution:
S o l u t i o n. To prove this, it is sufficient to show that the difference between the variable quantity $y=\frac{5 x+6}{6 x}$ and the constant $b=\frac{5}{6}$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$ is an infinitely small quantity. Transforming this difference, we get

$$
\frac{5 x+6}{6 x}-\frac{5}{6}=\frac{(5 x+6)-5 x}{6 x}=\frac{6}{6 x}=\frac{1}{x}
$$

Since, by formula (1.40), the quantity $\frac{1}{x}$ as $x \rightarrow \infty$ is infinitely small, then

$$
\frac{5 x+6}{6 x}-\frac{5}{6}=\alpha
$$

where $\alpha$ is an infinitely small quantity. This means that

$$
\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} \frac{5 x+6}{6 x}=\frac{5}{6}
$$

original.problem: Example 9. The function $f(x)=a e^{-|x|}$ is given. For what value of $a$ can it be considered as the probability density function of some random variable $X$?
original.solution:
Solution. If $f(x)$ is a probability density, then condition (2.3.6) must be satisfied. Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} a e^{-|x|} d x=a \int_{-\infty}^{0} e^{x} d x+a \int_{0}^{+\infty} e^{-x} d x=\left.a e^{x}\right|_{-\infty} ^{0}-\left.a e^{-x}\right|_{0} ^{+\infty}= \\
& =a(1-0)-a(0-1)=2 a=1, \quad \text { i.e. } a=1 / 2
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the function $p(x)=\frac{1}{2} e^{-|x|}$ is the probability density function of some random variable.

Example 1. Prove that the Heaviside function

$$
\eta(t)= \begin{cases}1, & t>0 \\ 0, & t<0\end{cases}
$$

is an original, and find its image (Laplace transform).
original.solution:
Solution.

1. Conditions a)-b) are obviously satisfied. Since the function $\eta(t)$ is bounded, its growth exponent $s=0$.
2. We find the image $F(p)$ using formula (1):

$$
F(p)=\int_{0}^{\infty} \eta(t) e^{-p t} d t=-\left.\frac{1}{p} e^{-p t}\right|_{0} ^{\infty}=\frac{1}{p}
$$

since from $\left|e^{-p t}\right|=e^{\operatorname{Re}(-p t)}=e^{-t \operatorname{Re} p}$ it follows that

$$
\lim _{t \rightarrow+\infty} e^{-p t}=0 \quad \text { for } \quad \operatorname{Re} p>s=0
$$

Answer. $\quad \eta(t) \longleftrightarrow \frac{1}{p}$

4. (Continuation of problem I.6.3.) The sequence of values $S_{0}=0$, $S_{1}=\xi_{1}, S_{2}=\xi_{1}+\xi_{2}, \ldots, S_{n}=\xi_{1}+\ldots+\xi_{n}$ can be considered as the trajectory of a particle's random walk, starting from zero and moving up or down by one unit at integer moments in time.

Now, let's assume that the walk occurs at moments of time $\Delta, 2 \Delta, \ldots, n \Delta$, where $\Delta>0$, and at each step, the particle moves up or down by an amount $\Delta x$. Instead of the probabilities $P_{n}(k)=\mathrm{P}\left\{S_{n}=k\right\}$ introduced in the previous problem, we consider the probabilities

$$
P_{n \Delta}(k \Delta x)=\mathrm{P}\left\{S_{n \Delta}=k \Delta x\right\}
$$

By analogy with the recurrence relations (**) we obtain that

$$
\begin{aligned}
P_{(n+1) \Delta}(k \Delta x)-P_{n \Delta}(k \Delta x)=\frac{1}{2}\left[P_{n \Delta}((k\right. & +1) \Delta x)- \\
& \left.-2 P_{n \Delta}(k \Delta x)+P_{n \Delta}((k-1) \Delta x)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

i.e., the "discrete version of the first derivative with respect to time" coincides, up to a factor of $\frac{1}{2}$, with the "discrete version of the second derivative with respect to the spatial variable."

Let $\Delta x=\sqrt{\Delta}$ and for $t>0$ and $x \in \mathbb{R}$, we will perform the limiting transition as $n \rightarrow \infty$ and $k \rightarrow \infty$ such that $n \Delta \rightarrow t, k \sqrt{\Delta} \rightarrow x$. Show that under such a limiting transition:

(a) the limit $P_{t}(x)=\lim P_{n \Delta}(k \sqrt{\Delta}) / \sqrt{\Delta}$ exists;

(b) the limiting functions $P_{t}(x)$ satisfy the "diffusion" heat equation

$$
\frac{\partial P_{t}(x)}{\partial t}=\frac{1}{2} \frac{\partial^{2} P_{t}(x)}{\partial x^{2}} \quad \text { (Bachelier, Einstein). }
$$
original.solution:
Solution. (a) By the local limit theorem

$$
P_{t}(x)=\lim _{\Delta \rightarrow 0} \frac{P_{n \Delta}(k \sqrt{\Delta})}{\sqrt{\Delta}}=\lim _{\Delta \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi n \Delta}} e^{-\frac{k^{2}}{2 n}}=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{\pi t}} e^{-\frac{x^{2}}{2 t}}
$$

(b) By direct calculation of the partial derivatives of the function $P_{t}(x)$ from part (a) of this problem, we obtain

$$
\frac{\partial P_{t}(x)}{\partial t}=\frac{x^{2}-t}{t^{2} \sqrt{2 \pi t}} e^{-\frac{x^{2}}{2 t}}, \quad \frac{\partial^{2} P_{t}(x)}{\partial x^{2}}=\frac{\sqrt{2}\left(x^{2}-t\right)}{t^{2} \sqrt{\pi t}} e^{-\frac{x^{2}}{2 t}}
$$

Thus, the functions $P_{t}(x)$ satisfy the "diffusion" heat equation.

original.problem: 24. Let the set $C$ be closed in $\mathbb{R}$. Construct a distribution function $F$ for which $\operatorname{supp} F=C$.
original.solution:
Solution. The set $\bar{C}$ is open in $\mathbb{R}$, and thus can be represented as $\bigcup_{n} I_{n}$, where $I_{n}$ are pairwise non-intersecting intervals. For $x \in I_{n}$, let $F(x)=\operatorname{arctg} a_{n}$, where $a_{n}$ is an arbitrary point in the interval $I_{n}$. Extend $F$ to the boundary points $D$ of the set $\bar{C}$ by the limit of $F(x)$ from the right, $x \in \bar{C}$. The set $C \backslash D$ is open, so it equals $\bigcup_{n} J_{n}$, where $J_{n}$ are pairwise non-intersecting intervals. On a fixed $J_{n}$, define $F$ by the formula $F(x)=\operatorname{arctg} x$. Normalizing $F$:

$$
\frac{F(x)-F(-\infty)}{F(\infty)-F(-\infty)}
$$

we obtain the desired distribution function.

\]

\]

$$

$$
0=\lim _{x \rightarrow \infty} f(x)0$ the equality holds

$$
\lambda\left(x \in[0,1]: \varlimsup_{n} f(x+n)>\varepsilon\right)=0

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lambda\left(x \in[0,1]: \overline{\lim _{n}} f(x+n)>\varepsilon\right) \leqslant \lambda\left(\bigcup_{n=N}^{\infty}\{x \in[0,1]: f(x+n)>\varepsilon\}\right) \leqslant \\

38. Provide an example of random variables $\xi_{n}, n \geqslant 1$, such that

$$
\mathrm{E} \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \xi_{n} \neq \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mathrm{E} \xi_{n}
$$
original.solution:
Solution. Define $\xi_{n}, n \geqslant 1$, by

$$
\xi_{n}=n I(n U \leqslant 1)-(n-1) I((n-1) U \leqslant 1),
$$

where $U$ is a random variable with a uniform distribution on $[0,1]$. Then

$$
\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \xi_{n}=\lim _{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \xi_{i}=\lim _{n} n I(n U \leqslant 1)=0
$$

with probability one. Thus

$$
\mathrm{E} \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \xi_{n}=0 \neq 1=\lim _{n} \mathrm{E} n I(n U \leqslant 1)=\lim _{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathrm{E} \xi_{i}=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \mathrm{E} \xi_{n}
$$

original.problem: 59. Let $\mathrm{P}(X \in[a, b])=1$ for some $-\infty < a < b < \infty$ and $b - a > 0$.
original.solution:
Solution. The function $f(x)=(x-\mathrm{E} X)^{2}$ is convex, therefore

$$
(X-\mathrm{E} X)^{2} \leqslant \frac{X-a}{b-a}(b-\mathrm{E} X)^{2}+\frac{b-X}{b-a}(a-\mathrm{E} X)^{2}
$$

so that

$\mathrm{D} X \leqslant \sup _{c}\left\{\frac{c-a}{b-a}(b-c)^{2}+\frac{b-c}{b-a}(a-c)^{2}\right\}=\sup _{c}(c-a)(b-c)=\frac{(b-a)^{2}}{4}$, where the supremum is taken over all $c \in[a, b]$. The maximum is achieved when

$$
\mathrm{P}(X=a)=\mathrm{P}(X=b)=\frac{1}{2}
$$

Reasoning similarly, we find that

$$
e^{X-\mathrm{E} X} \leqslant \frac{X-a}{b-a} e^{b-\mathrm{E} X}+\frac{b-X}{b-a} e^{a-\mathrm{E} X}
$$

and

$$
\mathrm{E}^{X} \leqslant \max _{c}\left\{\frac{c}{d} e^{d-c}+\frac{d-c}{d} e^{-c}\right\}
$$

where $d=b-a$, and $c(=\mathrm{E} X-a)$ lies in $[0, d]$. Direct verification shows that the maximum is achieved when

$$
c^{*}=\frac{e^{d}-1-d}{e^{d}-1} \quad(\leqslant d / 2)
$$

and when

$$
\mathrm{P}(X \in\{a, b\})=1, \quad \mathrm{E} X=c^{*}+a
$$

Let's turn to the third upper bound. Due to the convexity of the function $f(x)=1 / x$ (for $x>0$) we have

$$
\frac{1}{X} \leqslant \frac{X-a}{b-a} \frac{1}{b}+\frac{b-X}{b-a} \frac{1}{a}
$$

and

$$
\mathrm{E} X \cdot \mathrm{E} \frac{1}{X} \leqslant \sup _{c}\left\{\frac{c-a}{b-a} \frac{c}{b}+\frac{b-c}{b-a} \frac{c}{a}\right\}=\frac{(a+b)^{2}}{4 a b}
$$

where $c$ lies in $[a, b]$. The maximum is achieved when

$$
\mathrm{P}(X=a)=\mathrm{P}(X=b)=\frac{1}{2}
$$

original.problem: 79. When determining the Riemann integral of a function \( f = f(x) \), it is not assumed that this function is Borel measurable. Provide an example of a function \( f(x) \) that is not Borel measurable but is Riemann integrable on the interval \([0,1]\).
original.solution: Solution. The set of Borel subsets of the interval $[0,1]$ has the power of the continuum $\mathfrak{c}$, while the power of Lebesgue subsets is $2^{\mathfrak{c}}$ (see problem II.2.28). From this, it follows that if $\mathscr{C}$ is a Cantor set on $[0,1]$, then there exists a subset $C \subseteq \mathscr{C}$ which is not Borel and has Lebesgue measure zero. According to the criterion for the Riemann integrability of a function (see problem II.6.72), the function $f(x)=I_{C}(x)$, although not Borel, is Riemann integrable, and moreover, $\int_{0}^{1} f(x) d x=0$.

original.problem: 77. Provide an example of a function $f=f(x)$ on $[0,1]$, which is bounded and Lebesgue integrable, but for which it is impossible to find a function $g=g(x)$, Riemann integrable and coinciding with $f=f(x)$ almost everywhere according to the Lebesgue measure on $[0,1]$.
original.solution:
Solution. As $f$, one can take the indicator of a nowhere dense set $\mathscr{C}$ with positive Lebesgue measure. Then the set of discontinuity points of the function $f$ is precisely $\mathscr{C}$, and by the criterion for Riemann integrability (see problem II.6.72), $f$ is not Riemann integrable. On the other hand, the measure of the set of discontinuity points of any function $g$ that coincides with $f$ almost everywhere with respect to Lebesgue measure is positive, and thus $g$ is also not Riemann integrable.

The set $\mathscr{C}$ can be constructed similarly to the Cantor set. Specifically, one can take the interval $[0,1]$ and remove the "middle" interval, i.e., the one whose midpoint coincides with the midpoint of the initial interval, and whose length is four times smaller. The result will be the union of two intervals $[0,3 / 8]$ and $[5 / 8,1]$, from which one should also remove a "middle" interval of total length $1 / 8$. Repeating this procedure countably many times, we obtain a nowhere dense set $\mathscr{C}$, the Lebesgue measure of which is one minus the total length of the removed intervals

$$
\frac{1}{4}+\frac{1}{8}+\frac{1}{16}+\ldots=\frac{1}{2}
$$

In other words, the measure of the set $\mathscr{C}$ is $1 / 2$.

Remark. The set $\mathscr{C}$ constructed is commonly known as the Smith-Volterra-Cantor set.

78. Newton used the concept of the integral as an operation inverse to differentiation. In other words, a function $f=f(x)$ on $[a, b]$, $a<b$, was considered integrable if there existed an antiderivative $F=F(x)$ such that $F^{\prime}(x)=f(x)$ on $[a, b]$ (one-sided derivatives are taken at the endpoints $a$ and $b$). $$
\text { (N) } \int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x=F(b)-F(a)
$$

$$
\text { (N) } \int_{0}^{1} f(x) d x
$$

Solution. As $f(x)$, one should take $F^{\prime}(x)$, where

$$
F(x)=x^{2} \sin \frac{1}{x^{2}}
$$

Remark. In this context, we will present the construction of the generalized Riemann integral, which includes, as can be shown, the Lebesgue, Riemann, and Newton integrals (see [44]). Specifically, the number $I=(\mathrm{GR}) \int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x$ is a generalized Riemann integral if for any $\varepsilon>0$ there exists a function $\delta=\delta(x)$ on $[a, b]$ such that

$$
\left|\sum_{i=1}^{n} f\left(\omega_{i}\right)\left(x_{i}-x_{i-1}\right)-I\right| \leqslant \varepsilon
$$

when $a=x_{0}<x_{1}<\ldots<x_{n}=b, \omega_{i} \in\left[x_{i-1}, x_{i}\right]$ and $\left|x_{i}-x_{i-1}\right| \leqslant \delta\left(\omega_{i}\right)$.

20. Prove the following version of Fatou's lemma for conditional mathematical expectations.

Let $(\Omega, \mathscr{F}, \mathrm{P})$ be a probability space and $\left(\xi_{n}\right)_{n \geqslant 1}$ be a sequence of random variables such that the expectations $\mathrm{E} \xi_{n}, n \geqslant 1$, and $\mathrm{E} \underline{\lim } \xi_{n}$ (which may take values $\pm \infty$) are defined.

$$
\varlimsup_{n} \mathrm{E}\left(\xi_{n}^{-} I\left(\xi_{n}^{-} \geqslant k\right) \mid \mathscr{G}\right) \rightarrow 0 \quad \text { a.s., } \quad k \rightarrow \infty
$$

Then

$$
\mathrm{E}\left(\lim \xi_{n} \mid \mathscr{G}\right) \leqslant \underline{\lim } \mathrm{E}\left(\xi_{n} \mid \mathscr{G}\right) \quad \text { a.s. }
$$
original.solution:
Solution. Let $\xi_{n}^{k}=\xi_{n}^{+}-\xi_{n}^{-} I\left(\xi_{n}^{-}<k\right), k \geqslant 1$. Then $\xi_{n}^{k} \geqslant \xi_{n}$,

$$
\frac{\lim }{n} \mathrm{E}\left(\xi_{n} \mid \mathscr{G}\right) \leqslant \frac{\lim }{n} \mathrm{E}\left(\xi_{n}^{k} \mid \mathscr{G}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \mathrm{E}\left(\left.\frac{\lim }{n} \xi_{n} \right\rvert\, \mathscr{G}\right) \leqslant \mathrm{E}\left(\left.\frac{\lim }{n} \xi_{n}^{k} \right\rvert\, \mathscr{G}\right) \quad \text { a.s. }
$$

Moreover, according to part d) of Theorem 2 in V1.II.7, we have

$$

$$

Thus, it is sufficient to show that

$$
\lim _{n} \mathrm{E}\left(\xi_{n}^{k} \mid \mathscr{G}\right) \rightarrow \frac{\lim }{n} \mathrm{E}\left(\xi_{n} \mid \mathscr{G}\right), \quad k \rightarrow \infty
$$

The last statement follows from the condition of the problem:

$$
\left|\varliminf_{n} \mathrm{E}\left(\xi_{n}^{k} \mid \mathscr{G}\right)-\frac{\lim }{n} \mathrm{E}\left(\xi_{n} \mid \mathscr{G}\right)\right| \leqslant \varlimsup_{n} \mathrm{E}\left(\xi_{n}^{-} I\left(\xi_{n}^{-} \geqslant k\right) \mid \mathscr{G}\right) \rightarrow 0, \quad k \rightarrow \infty . \square
$$

84. (a) Consider the equation

$$
Z_{t}=B_{t}+\int_{0}^{t} Z_{s-} d A_{s}
$$

where $A_{t}$ and $B_{t}$ are right-continuous (for $t \geqslant 0$) and have left limits (for $t>0$) functions of (locally) bounded variation.

Show that in the class of locally bounded functions, this equation has a unique solution $\mathscr{E}_{t}(A, B)+B_{0} \mathscr{E}_{t}(A)$, where

$$
\mathscr{E}_{t}(A, B)=\mathscr{E}_{t}(A) \int_{0}^{t} \frac{d B_{s}}{\mathscr{E}_{s}(A)}
$$

and the stochastic exponential $\mathscr{E}_{t}(A)$ is defined by the formula

$$
\mathscr{E}_{t}(A)=e^{A_{t}-A_{0}} \prod_{0<s \leqslant t}\left(1+\Delta A_{s}\right) e^{-\sum_{0<s \leqslant t} \Delta A_{s}}
$$

where $\Delta A_{s}=A_{s}-A_{s-}$ for $s>0$, and $\Delta A_{0}=0$.

Remark. If $A_{t}$ is a function of locally bounded variation, then $A_{t}$ can be discontinuous at no more than a countable number of points, and

$$
\prod_{0<s \leqslant t}\left(1+\Delta A_{s}\right) \quad \text{and} \quad e^{-\sum_{0<s \leqslant t} \Delta A_{s}}
$$

are well-defined on $\mathbb{R}_{+}$ and also have (locally) bounded variation.
(b) Suppose that for all $t \geqslant 0$ the inequalities

$$
X_{t} \leqslant B_{t}+\int_{0}^{t} X_{s-} d A_{s}
$$

hold, where $X=X_{t}$ is a locally bounded function, and the functions $A=A_{t}$ and $B=B_{t}$ are the same as in part (a). Assuming that $A_{t}$ is non-decreasing in $t$, establish the Gronwall-Bellman inequality

$$
X_{t} \leqslant \mathscr{E}_{t}(A, B)+B_{0} \mathscr{E}_{t}(A), \quad t \geqslant 0
$$

Solution. (a) Let $C_{t}=A_{t}-\sum_{00$, and $G_{0}=1$ by the formula for integration by parts we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathscr{E}_{t}(A)=F_{t} G_{t} & =1+\int_{0}^{t} F_{s} d G_{s}+\int_{0}^{t} G_{s-} d F_{s}= \\
& =1+\sum_{00$ for all $0 \leqslant s \leqslant t$ and, secondly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
Y_{t} \leqslant \int_{[0, t]} Y_{t_{1}-} d A_{t_{1}} \leqslant \int_{[0, t]} d A_{t_{1}} & \int_{\left[0, t_{1}\right)} Y_{t_{2}-} d A_{t_{2}} \leqslant \ldots \\
& \ldots \leqslant M \int_{[0, t]} d A_{t_{1}} \int_{\left[0, t_{1}\right)} d A_{t_{2}} \ldots \int_{\left[0, t_{n-1}\right)} d A_{t_{n}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Consider i.i.d. random variables $\left(\xi_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{n}$ taking values in the interval $[0, t]$, with the distribution function

$$
F(s)=\frac{A_{s}-A_{0}}{A_{t}-A_{0}}, \quad 0 \leqslant s \leqslant t
$$

and defined on some probability space ( $\Omega, \mathscr{F}, \mathrm{P}$ ). Then as $n \rightarrow \infty$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{[0, t]} d A_{t_{1}} \int_{\left[0, t_{1}\right)} d A_{t_{2}} \ldots \int_{\left[0, t_{n-1}\right)} d A_{t_{n}}=\left(A_{t}-A_{0}\right)^{n} \mathrm{P}\left(\xi_{1}>\xi_{2}>\ldots>\xi_{n}\right)= \\
& \quad=\frac{\left(A_{t}-A_{0}\right)^{n}}{n!} \cdot \mathrm{P}\left(\text { all } \xi_{i} \text { are distinct, } 1 \leqslant i \leqslant n\right) \leqslant \frac{\left(A_{t}-A_{0}\right)^{n}}{n!} \rightarrow 0 .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, $Y_{t} \leqslant 0$ and, therefore, $X_{t} \leqslant Z_{t}$ for each $t \geqslant 0$.

original.problem:
69. (Gamma and Beta functions, [56].) In this problem, we are to obtain an integral representation for $n!$ and thereby introduce the gamma function as L. Euler did. First, show that

$$
\int_{0}^{1} x^{\alpha-1}(1-x)^{n} d x=\frac{n!}{\alpha(\alpha+1) \ldots(\alpha+n)}, \quad \alpha>0, \quad n=0,1,2, \ldots
$$

From this, derive that for $a>0$

$$
\int_{0}^{1}\left(\frac{1-x^{a}}{a}\right)^{n} d x=\frac{n!}{(1+a) \ldots(1+a n)}
$$

By taking the limit as $a \rightarrow 0$, establish that

$$
\int_{0}^{1}(-\ln x)^{n} d x=n!
$$

The integral obtained was called the first Euler integral by A. M. Legendre, and the corresponding function was denoted by the letter $\Gamma$ (gamma):

$$
\Gamma(s)=\int_{0}^{1}(-\ln x)^{s-1} d x, \quad s>0
$$

Show that the gamma function $\Gamma(s)$ admits another representation:

$$
\Gamma(s)=\int_{0}^{\infty} x^{s-1} e^{-x} d x
$$

From this, derive the recurrence property of the gamma function $\Gamma(s+1)=$ $=s \Gamma(s)$.

The second Euler integral (or beta function) is defined as integrals of the form

$$
\mathrm{B}(\alpha, \beta)=\int_{0}^{1} x^{\alpha-1}(1-x)^{\beta-1} d x, \quad \alpha, \beta>0
$$

By the relation (*) for any $\alpha, \beta \in \mathbb{N}$, we have

$$
\mathrm{B}(\alpha, \beta)=\frac{\Gamma(\alpha) \Gamma(\beta)}{\Gamma(\alpha+\beta)}
$$

Prove that this formula remains valid for any $\alpha, \beta>0$.
original.solution:
Solution. To establish the relation (*), it is sufficient to integrate by parts $n$ times. By transitioning to the new variable $z=x^{\alpha}$ and setting $\alpha=1/a$, we get

$$
\int_{0}^{1} x^{1/a-1}(1-x)^{n} d x=a^{n} \int_{0}^{1}\left(\frac{1-z^{a}}{a}\right)^{n} \frac{d z}{1/a}
$$

On the other hand,

$$
\frac{1}{a^{n+1}} \int_{0}^{1} x^{1/a-1}(1-x)^{n} d x=\frac{n!}{a(1+a) \ldots(1+an)}
$$

from which the second desired equality follows. As $a \rightarrow 0$ for all $x \in(0,1]$, we have

$$
\frac{1-x^{a}}{a}=\frac{1-e^{a \ln x}}{a} \rightarrow -\ln x \quad \text { and } \quad 0 \leqslant \frac{1-e^{a \ln x}}{a} \leqslant |\ln x| .
$$

Moreover, $\int_{0}^{1}|\ln x|^{n} d x<\infty$, since $|\ln x|=o(1 / \sqrt{x})$ as $x \rightarrow 0$. Therefore, by the Lebesgue dominated convergence theorem,

$$
\int_{0}^{1}\left(\frac{1-x^{a}}{a}\right)^{n} d x \rightarrow \int_{0}^{1}(-\ln x)^{n} d x
$$

It is also clear that

$$
\frac{n!}{(1+a) \ldots(1+an)} \rightarrow n!
$$

from which we obtain the third equality.

The second representation of the gamma function follows from the first by making a suitable change of variables ($x=e^{-z}$). Now let's derive the recurrence property:

$$
\Gamma(s+1)=\int_{0}^{\infty} x^{s} e^{-x} d x=-\left.x^{s} e^{-x}\right|_{0} ^{\infty}+\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-x} d x^{s}=s \Gamma(s)
$$

Moreover,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Gamma(\alpha) \Gamma(\beta)=\int_{0}^{\infty} x^{\alpha-1} e^{-x} d x \cdot \int_{0}^{\infty} y^{\beta-1} e^{-y} d y= \\
& \quad=\int_{\mathbb{R}_{+}^{2}} x^{\alpha-1} y^{\beta-1} e^{-(x+y)} d x d y=\int_{0 \leqslant x \leqslant u} x^{\alpha-1}(u-x)^{\beta-1} e^{-u} d x d u= \\
& \quad=\int_{(u, v) \in \mathbb{R}_{+} \times[0,1]}(u v)^{\alpha-1}(u-u v)^{\beta-1} e^{-u} u d v d u=\Gamma(\alpha+\beta) \mathrm{B}(\alpha, \beta) .
\end{aligned}
$$

33. Prove Egorov's Theorem.

Let $\xi, \xi_{1}, \xi_{2}, \ldots$ be a sequence of random variables such that $\xi_{n} \rightarrow \xi$ almost surely. Then for any $\varepsilon>0$, there exists a set $A_{\varepsilon} \in \mathscr{F}$ with $\mathrm{P}\left(A_{\varepsilon}\right) \geqslant 1-\varepsilon$, on which the uniform convergence $\xi_{n}(\omega) \rightarrow \xi(\omega), \omega \in A_{\varepsilon}$ holds.
original.solution:
Solution. By the definition of convergence with probability one

$$
\xi_{n} \rightarrow \xi \text { a.s. } \Leftrightarrow \sup _{i \geqslant n}\left|\xi_{i}-\xi\right| \rightarrow 0 \text { a.s. }
$$

Therefore, $\sup _{i \geqslant n}\left|\xi_{i}-\xi\right| \xrightarrow{p} 0$ and, consequently, there exists a sequence of indices $n_{k} \uparrow \infty$, for which

$$
\mathrm{P}\left(\sup _{i \geqslant n_{k}}\left|\xi_{i}-\xi\right|>k^{-1}\right) \leqslant \frac{\varepsilon}{2^{k}}
$$

On the set

$$
A_{\varepsilon}=\bigcap_{k=1}^{\infty}\left\{\sup _{i \geqslant n_{k}}\left|\xi_{i}-\xi\right| \leqslant k^{-1}\right\}
$$

uniform convergence $\xi_{n}(\omega) \rightarrow \xi(\omega), \omega \in A_{\varepsilon}$ holds. Moreover, the probability of the event $A_{\varepsilon}$ is at least $1-\varepsilon$. Indeed,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathrm{P}\left(A_{\varepsilon}\right) \geqslant 1-\mathrm{P}\left(\bar{A}_{\varepsilon}\right) \geqslant 1-\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \mathrm{P}\left(\sup _{i \geqslant n_{k}}\left|\xi_{i}-\xi\right|>k^{-1}\right) \geqslant \\
& \geqslant 1-\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{\varepsilon}{2^{k}}=1-\varepsilon
\end{aligned}
$$

This problem involves proving Egorov's Theorem, which is a significant result in probability theory. The proof requires establishing uniform convergence for a sequence of random variables under specific conditions, leveraging definitions, properties of probability, and the concept of convergence almost surely.

The key aspects of the task include formulating properties and demonstrating implications which are not just computational in nature. This means that the problem requires a deeper understanding of the underlying concepts and proof techniques rather than only executing computations.

original.problem: Example 1. Show that $y=C_{1} x+C_{2}$ is the general solution of the differential equation $y^{\prime \prime}=0$.
original.solution:
Solution. We will show that $y=C_{1} x+C_{2}$ satisfies the given equation for any values of the constants $C_{1}$ and $C_{2}$. Indeed, we have $y^{\prime}=C_{1}, y^{\prime \prime}=0$.

Now let the given arbitrary initial conditions be $\left.y\right|_{z=x_{0}}=y_{0}$, $\left.y^{\prime}\right|_{x=x_{0}}=y_{0}^{\prime}$. We will show that the constants $C_{1}$ and $C_{2}$ can be chosen such that $y=C_{1} x+C_{2}$ satisfies these conditions. We have $y=C_{1} x+C_{2}, y^{\prime}=C_{1}$. Setting $x=x_{0}$, we obtain the system

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
y_{0}=C_{1} x_{0}+C_{2} \\
y_{0}^{\prime}=C_{1}
\end{array}\right.
$$

from which $C_{1}=y_{0}^{\prime}$ and $C_{2}=y_{0}-x_{0} y_{0}^{\prime}$ are uniquely determined. Thus, the solution $y=y_{0}^{\prime}\left(x-x_{0}\right)+y_{0}$ satisfies the given initial conditions.

Geometrically, this means that through each point $M_{0}\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$ of the plane $x O y$ with a given slope $y_{0}^{\prime}$, there passes a unique straight line.

Specifying one initial condition, for example $\left.y\right|_{z=x_{0}}=y_{0}$, defines a pencil of lines centered at the point $M_{0}\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$, i.e., one initial condition is insufficient to select a unique solution.

## Problems for Independent Solution

316. The differential equation $y^{\prime \prime}=2 \sqrt{y^{\prime}}$ has two solutions $y_{1}(x) \equiv 0$, $y_{2}(x) \equiv \frac{x^{3}}{3}$, satisfying the initial conditions $\left.y\right|_{x=0}=0,\left.y^{\prime}\right|_{x=0}=0$. Why does this result not contradict the theorem of existence and uniqueness of the solution to the Cauchy problem?
317. Can the graphs of two solutions of the given equation touch each other at some point $(x_{0}, y_{0})$: a) for the equation $y^{\prime}=x^{2}+y^{2}$; b) for the equation $y^{\prime \prime}=x^{2}+y^{2}$; c) for the equation $y^{\prime \prime \prime}=x^{2}+y^{2}$?

In the following problems, show that the given functions are solutions of the specified equations:

318. $y=x(\sin x-\cos x), \quad y^{\prime \prime}+y=2(\cos x+\sin x)$.
319. $y=x^{2} \ln x, \quad x y^{\prime \prime \prime}=2$.
320. $x+C=e^{-y}, y^{\prime \prime}=\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{2}$.
321. $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x=1+e^{t}, \\ y=t e^{t},\end{array}(x-1) y^{\prime \prime}=1\right.$.
322. $\left\{\begin{array}{l}x=C_{1}+\frac{t^{4}}{4}, \\ y=C_{2}+\frac{t^{5}}{5},\end{array} y^{\prime \prime}\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{3}=1\right.$.

Show that the given functions are general solutions of the corresponding equations.

323. $y=C_{1} \sin x+C_{2} \cos x, \quad y^{\prime \prime}+y=0$.
324. $y=C_{1} e^{x}+C_{2} e^{2 x}+1, \quad y^{\prime \prime}-3 y^{\prime}+2 y=2$.

Show that the given relations are integrals (general or particular) of the specified equations.

325. $\left(x-C_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y-C_{2}\right)^{2}=1, \quad y^{\prime \prime}=\left(1+\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{2}\right)^{3 / 2}$,
326. $y^{2}=1+(1-x)^{2}, \quad\left(y^{\prime}\right)^{2}+y y^{\prime \prime}=1$.

## § 14. Differential Equations Admitting Order Reduction

We will indicate some types of differential equations that admit order reduction.

1. Equations of the form $y^{(n)}=f(x)$. After $n$-fold integration, the general solution is obtained:

$$
y=\underbrace{\int \ldots \int}_{n} f(x) \underbrace{d x \ldots d x}_{n}+C_{1} \frac{x^{n-1}}{(n-1)!}+C_{2} \frac{x^{n-2}}{(n-2)!}+\ldots+C_{n-1} x+C_{n}
$$

II. Equations that do not contain the unknown function and its derivatives up to order $k-1$ inclusive:

$$
F\left(x, y^{(k)}, y^{(k+1)}, \ldots, y^{(n)}\right)=0
$$

The order of such an equation can be reduced by $k$ units by the substitution $y^{(k)}(x)=p(x)$. Then the equation takes the form

$$
F\left(x, p, p^{\prime}, \ldots, p^{(n-k)}\right)=0
$$

From the last equation, if possible, we determine $p=f\left(x, C_{1}, C_{2}, \ldots, C_{n-k}\right)$, and then we find $y$ from the equation $y^{(k)}=f\left(x, C_{1}, C_{2}, \ldots, C_{n-k}\right)$ by $k$-fold integration.

III. Equations that do not contain the independent variable:

$$
F\left(y, y^{\prime}, y^{\prime \prime}, \ldots, y^{(n)}\right)=0
$$

The substitution $y^{\prime}=p$ allows reducing the order of the equation by one unit. Here, $p$ is considered as a new unknown function of $y$: $p=p(y)$. All derivatives $y^{\prime}, y^{\prime \prime}, \ldots, y^{(n)}$ are expressed in terms of derivatives of the new unknown function $p$ with respect to $y$:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& y^{\prime}=\frac{d y}{d x}=p \\
& y^{\prime \prime}=\frac{d p}{d x}=\frac{d p}{d y} \frac{d y}{d x}=p \frac{d p}{d y} \\
& y^{\prime \prime \prime}=\frac{d}{d x}\left(p \frac{d p}{d y}\right)=\frac{d}{d y}\left(p \frac{d p}{d y}\right) \frac{d y}{d x}=p^{2} \frac{d^{2} p}{d y^{2}}+p\left(\frac{d p}{d y}\right)^{2} \text { and so on. }
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting these expressions for $y^{\prime}, y^{\prime \prime}, \ldots, y^{(n)}$ into the equation, we obtain a differential equation of order $(n-1)$.

IV. Equations $F\left(x, y, y^{\prime}, \ldots, y^{(n)}\right)=0$, homogeneous with respect to the arguments $y, y^{\prime}, y^{\prime \prime}, \ldots, y^{(n)}$, i.e.,

$$
\boldsymbol{F}\left(x, t y, t y^{\prime}, \ldots, t y^{(n)}\right)=t^{k} F\left(x, y, y^{\prime}, \ldots, y^{(n)}\right)
$$

The order of such an equation can be reduced by one unit by the substitution $y=e^{\int z d x}$, where $z$ is a new unknown function of $x: z=z(x)$.

V. Equations written in differentials,

$$
F\left(x, y, d x, d y, d^{2} y, \ldots, d^{(n)} y\right)=0
$$

where the function $F$ is homogeneous with respect to its arguments $x, y, d x$, $d y, d^{2} y, \ldots, d^{n} y$, if we consider $x$ and $d x$ to be of the first dimension, and $y, d y, d^{2} y$ and so on to be of dimension $m$. Then $\frac{d y}{d x}$ will have dimension $m-1, \frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}}$ will have dimension $m-2$, and so on.

To reduce the order, the substitution $x=e^{t}, y=u e^{m t}$ is applied. As a result, we obtain a differential equation between $u$ and $t$ that does not explicitly contain $t$, i.e., it admits a reduction of order by one unit (case III).

We will consider examples for various cases of order reduction of a differential equation.

## § 17. Boundary Value Problems

Consider, for simplicity, a second-order equation

\[
y'' + p_1(x) y' + p_2(x) y = 0
\]

The coefficients \( p_1(x) \) and \( p_2(x) \) will be considered continuous in some interval \((a, b)\). Then each solution \( y(x) \) of equation (1) will be defined throughout this interval. In the future, instead of equation (1), we will consider an equation of the form

\[
\left[p(x) y'\right]' + q(x) y = 0, \quad p(x) > 0
\]

Equations (1) and (2) can be transformed into each other. Equations of the form (2) are called self-adjoint.

The solution of the differential equation

\[
\left[p(x) y'\right]' + q(x) y = 0
\]

is completely determined by the initial conditions \( y(x_0) = y_0, y'(x_0) = y_0' \). However, in many physical problems, it is necessary to find solutions defined in a different way. For example, the problem may be to find a solution of equation (2) that takes on specified values \( y(a) \) and \( y(b) \) at points \( a \) and \( b \). Usually, in such cases, the values of the solution are sought only for \( x \) in \((a, b)\). Thus, the specified values \( y(a) \) and \( y(b) \) are at the ends of the interval, so problems of this kind are called boundary value problems. In the future, we will base our interval on \((0, \pi)\) (the main interval), which does not reduce the generality of the arguments.

The general form of boundary conditions for a second-order equation is as follows:

\[
h_0 y(0) + h_1 y'(0) = A, \quad k_0 y(\pi) + k_1 y'(\pi) = B
\]

where \( h_0, h_1, k_0, k_1, A, B \) are given constants, and \( h_0, h_1, k_0, k_1 \) are not all zero simultaneously.

If \( A = B = 0 \), the boundary conditions are called homogeneous, for example:

1) \( y(0) = y(\pi) = 0 \)
2) \( h_0 y(0) = y'(0), \quad y'(\pi) = -h_1 y(\pi); \quad h_0, h_1 > 0 \),
3) \( y'(0) = y'(\pi) = 0 \)
4) \( y(0) = y(\pi), \quad y'(0) = y'(\pi) \).

In general, boundary value problems are not always solvable, i.e., there does not always exist a solution that takes on the required values at the ends of the interval. For example, the boundary value problem

\[
y'' = 0, \quad y(0) - y(\pi) = 1, \quad y'(0) + y'(\pi) = 0
\]

has no solution. The problem

\[
y'' + \lambda y = 0, \quad y(0) = y(\pi) = 0
\]

has a non-zero solution only for integer values of \(\sqrt{\lambda}\). Indeed, from the general solution of the differential equation (4)

\[
y = C_1 e^{\sqrt{-\lambda x}} + C_2 e^{-\sqrt{-\lambda x}}
\]

it follows that the boundary conditions are satisfied if and only if \(\lambda = n^2\) is the square of an integer \( n \). The corresponding solutions are the functions \( y_n = \sin nx \).

As can be seen from this example, if \( q \) in equation (2) is a function of the parameter \(\lambda\), then for known conditions, there exist values of the parameter for which the homogeneous boundary value problem for equation (2) has a non-zero solution. These values of \(\lambda\) are called eigenvalues, and the corresponding solutions of the boundary value problem are called eigenfunctions. The latter are defined up to an arbitrary constant factor. Thus, for the boundary value problem \( y'' + \lambda y = 0, y(0) = y(\pi) = 0 \), the numbers \( 1^2, 2^2, 3^2, \ldots \) and the functions \( \sin x, \sin 2x, \ldots \) are the eigenvalues and eigenfunctions, respectively.

In addition to simple eigenvalues, where one eigenvalue corresponds to one eigenfunction (up to a constant factor), there are multiple eigenvalues, where an eigenvalue \(\lambda_0\) corresponds to two or more linearly independent eigenfunctions.

When solving boundary value problems (for linear homogeneous differential equations), the following approach is taken: find the general solution of the given differential equation

\[
y = C_1 y_1(x) + C_2 y_2(x) + \ldots + C_n y_n(x)
\]

where \( y_1(x), y_2(x), \ldots, y_n(x) \) are linearly independent solutions. Then require that this solution \( y(x) \) satisfies the given boundary conditions. This leads to a certain linear system of equations for determining \( C_1, C_2, \ldots, C_n \). By solving this system, if possible, find the solution of the given boundary value problem. In this process, if the problem of finding eigenvalues arises, the condition for the existence of a non-zero solution of the system determining \( C_1, C_2, \ldots, C_n \) is the condition that determines the eigenvalues. This is generally a transcendental equation for \(\lambda\).

original.problem: 54. Continuous functions \( f, g: [0; 1] \rightarrow [0; 1] \) have the property that \( f(g(x)) = g(f(x)) \) for any \( x \) from \([0; 1]\). Prove that if \( f \) is increasing, then there exists \( a \in [0; 1] \) such that \( f(a) = g(a) = a \).

A monotonic bounded sequence $\left\{x_{n}\right\}$ has a limit $a$, which should be taken as the desired "fixed point" common to $f$ and $g$.

original.problem: 25.13. Prove that any increasing (or at least non-decreasing) sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ that is bounded above has a limit (Weierstrass).
original.solution:
25.13. A non-decreasing sequence bounded above is bounded, since $a_{n} \geqslant a_{1}$ for all $n$. Therefore, according to the Bolzano-Weierstrass theorem (problem 25.11), the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ has a limit point $c$. First, we will prove that the limit point is unique. Suppose there are two limit points: $c_{1}c_{2}-\frac{\varepsilon}{2}$. This means that $x_{n}>c_{2}-\frac{\varepsilon}{2}$ for $n \geqslant N$. But then $x_{n}-c_{1}>\frac{\varepsilon}{2}$, so $c_{1}$ cannot be a limit point.

Let $c$ be the limit point. Then $x_{n} \leqslant c$ for all $n$ (otherwise, all points $x_{m}$, where $m \geqslant n$, lie outside some neighborhood of the point $c$). Therefore, for each $\varepsilon>0$, one can choose $N$ such that $c-\varepsilon<x_{N} \leqslant c$. Then $c-\varepsilon<x_{n} \leqslant c$ for $n \geqslant N$.

This problem involves proving the existence of a limit for an increasing (or non-decreasing) sequence that is bounded above. The solution includes arguments related to limit points and the properties of bounded sequences, referencing the Bolzano-Weierstrass theorem.

original.problem: 26.11. The function $f(x)$ is continuous on the interval $[a, b]$ and takes values of different signs at its endpoints. Prove that $f\left(x_{0}\right)=0$ for some point $x_{0}$ in this interval (Intermediate Value Theorem).
original.solution: 26.11. Let for definiteness $f(a)>0$ and $f(b)<0$, then if $f(c) \leq 0$, we set $a_{1}=a$ and $b_{1}=c$; if $f(c)>0$, we set $a_{2}=c$ and $b_{2}=b_{1}$ (we assume that $f(c) \neq 0$, since otherwise the proof is immediately complete). Then we take the midpoint of the interval $\left[a_{2}, b_{2}\right]$ and repeat the same process, and so on. As a result, we obtain a non-decreasing sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ and a non-increasing sequence $\left\{b_{n}\right\}$. These sequences are bounded and $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(b_{n}-a_{n}\right)=0$. Therefore, by the Weierstrass theorem, $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} a_{n}=x_{0}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} b_{n}$. By construction, $f\left(a_{n}\right) \geqslant 0$ for all $n$. The function $f(x)$ is continuous, so $f\left(x_{0}\right) \geqslant 0$. On the other hand, $f\left(b_{n}\right) \leqslant 0$, so $f\left(x_{0}\right) \leqslant 0$. Therefore, $f\left(x_{0}\right)=0$. It is also clear that $a \leqslant x_{0} \leqslant b$.

26.18. Prove that a function $f(x)$, continuous on the interval $[a, b]$, attains a maximum and a minimum at some points of this interval (Weierstrass).

## 26.7. Convex Functions

A function $f(x)$ defined on the interval $[a, b]$ is called convex if

$$
f\left(\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}}{2}\right) \leqslant \frac{f\left(x_{1}\right)+f\left(x_{2}\right)}{2}
$$

for all $x_{1}$ and $x_{2}$ lying on the interval $[a, b]$.

Geometrically, inequality (1) means that the midpoint of any chord of the curve $y=f(x)$ lies above this curve (or on the curve itself).

A function $f(x)$ is called concave if the function $-f(x)$ is convex.
original.solution: 26.18. We will prove that on the interval $[a, b]$, there exists a point $x_{0}$ such that $f\left(x_{0}\right)=M$, where $M$ is the least upper bound of the set of values of $f(x)$ for all points $x$ in the interval $[a, b]$. (The proof for the greatest lower bound is analogous.) First, note that the set of values of the function $f(x)$ is bounded (Problem 26.16), so the least upper bound $M$ exists (Problem 25.45). Therefore, we can choose a sequence of points $x_{n}$ in the interval $[a, b]$ such that $M-1 / n \leqslant f\left(x_{n}\right) \leqslant M$. We can select a convergent subsequence $\left\{x_{n_{k}}\right\}$ from the bounded sequence $\left\{x_{n}\right\}$. If $\lim _{k \rightarrow \infty} x_{n_{k}}=x_{0}$, then $a \leqslant x_{0} \leqslant b$ and $f\left(x_{0}\right)=M$.

This means that at some interior point $x_{0}$ of the interval $[a, b]$ the function $f(x)$ attains a maximum or minimum value, so by Fermat's theorem (problem 28.36) $f^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)=0$.

original.problem:
28.45. The functions $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ are differentiable on the interval $[a, b]$, and the derivative $g'(x)$ does not vanish at any interior point of this interval. Prove that there exists an interior point $x_0$ of the interval $[a, b]$ such that

$$
\frac{f(b)-f(a)}{g(b)-g(a)}=\frac{f'\left(x_{0}\right)}{g'\left(x_{0}\right)} \quad(\text{Cauchy})
$$

## 28.8. Inequalities
original.solution:
28.45. Consider the auxiliary function

$$
F(x)=(f(b)-f(a))(g(x)-g(a))-(f(x)-f(a))(g(b)-g(a))
$$

It is clear that

$$
F^{\prime}(x)=(f(b)-f(a)) g^{\prime}(x)-f^{\prime}(x)(g(b)-g(a))
$$

and $F(a)=F(b)=0$. Therefore, we can apply Rolle's theorem (problem 28.37) to the function $F(x)$. As a result, we obtain that there exists an interior point $x_{0}$ for which

$$
(f(b)-f(a)) g^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)-f^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)(g(b)-g(a))=0
$$

By the condition, $g^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right) \neq 0$. It is also easy to see that $g(b)-g(a) \neq 0$, since otherwise, by Rolle's theorem, there would be an interior point $x_{1}$ for which $g^{\prime}\left(x_{1}\right)=0$. Therefore, we can divide equation (1) by $g^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)(g(b)-g(a))$ and obtain the required result.

The function $f(x)$ is uniformly continuous on the interval $[a, b]$ (problem 26.26), so for any $\varepsilon>0$ we can choose $\delta>0$ such that if the distance between points $x^{\prime}$ and $x^{\prime \prime}$ on the interval $[a, b]$ is less than $\delta$, then $\left|f\left(x^{\prime}\right)-f\left(x^{\prime \prime}\right)\right|<\varepsilon$. Therefore, if the largest length of the subinterval of the partition is less than $\delta$, then $M_{k}-m_{k}<\varepsilon$, and thus,

$$
S-s=\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}\left(M_{k}-m_{k}\right)\left(x_{k+1}-x_{k}\right)<\varepsilon \sum_{k=0}^{n-1}\left(x_{k+1}-x_{k}\right)=\varepsilon(b-a)
$$

Thus, if the largest length of the subinterval of the partition tends to zero, then the difference $S-s$ tends to zero.

original.problem: 29.19. Let $f(x)$ be a continuous function on the interval $[a, b]$. Prove that there exists a point $\xi$ in the interval $[a, b]$ such that $\int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x=f(\xi)(b-a)$.
original.solution: 29.19. Let $M$ and $m$ be the maximum and minimum values of the function $f(x)$ on the interval $[a, b]$. Then each integral sum is bounded between $m(b-a)$ and $M(b-a)$. Therefore, $\int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x=c(b-a)$, where the number $c$ is between $m$ and $M$. A continuous function on an interval takes all values between $m$ and $M$, so $c=f(\xi)$ for some point $\xi$ in the interval $[a, b]$.

29.55. Prove that for any natural $n \geqslant 3$ there exists a polynomial $f(x)$ of degree $n$ with real coefficients and roots $a_{1}<a_{2}<\ldots<a_{n}$, for which

$$
\int_{a_{1}}^{a_{2}}|f(x)| d x=\int_{a_{2}}^{a_{3}}|f(x)| d x=\ldots=\int_{a_{n}}^{a_{n-1}}|f(x)| d x
$$

### 29.12. Improper Integrals

The integral $\int_{a}^{b} f(x) d x$ is called improper in two cases:

1) if the function $f(x)$ is defined only on the interval $(a, b)$, but not on the entire segment $[a, b]$;
2) if $a=-\infty$ and/or $b=\infty$.

An improper integral is understood as the limit of the integral $\int^{v} f(x) d x$, as $u \rightarrow a+$ (respectively, $u \rightarrow-\infty$) and $v \rightarrow b-$ (respectively, $v \rightarrow+\infty$). It is meant that $u$ and $v$ tend to the specified limits independently of each other. 29.56. Compute the improper integral $\int_{0}^{1} x^{a} d x$, where

Then we obtain the following condition: $F\left(a_{2}\right)-F\left(a_{1}\right)=F\left(a_{2}\right)-F\left(a_{3}\right)=F\left(a_{4}\right)-$ $-F\left(a_{3}\right)=F\left(a_{4}\right)-F\left(a_{5}\right)=\ldots$, i.e., $F\left(a_{1}\right)=F\left(a_{3}\right)=F\left(a_{5}\right)=\ldots$ and $F\left(a_{2}\right)=$ $=F\left(a_{4}\right)=F\left(a_{6}\right)=\ldots$

We will show that if $F(x)=T_{n+1}(x)$ is a Chebyshev polynomial, then $F$ has the required property. From the equality $T_{n+1}(\cos \varphi)=$ $=\cos (n+1) \varphi$ it follows that $-\sin \varphi T_{n+1}^{\prime}(\cos \varphi)=-(n+1) \sin (n+1) \varphi$. Therefore, if $T_{n+1}^{\prime}(\cos \varphi)=0$, then $\sin (n+1) \varphi=0$, and hence $T_{n+1}(\cos \varphi)=\cos (n+1) \varphi= \pm 1$. $$
1+\frac{1}{3}\left(\frac{1}{(2 n+1)^{2}}+\frac{1}{(2 n+1)^{4}}+\ldots\right)=1+\frac{1}{12 n(n+1)}

e a_{n+1} < a_n e^{\frac{1}{12 n}}. \text{ Therefore, the sequence } \left\{a_{n} e^{-\frac{1}{12 n}}\right\} \text{ is increasing, while the sequence } \left\{a_{n}\right\} \text{ is decreasing.} \text{ Moreover, } a_{1} e^{-\frac{1}{12}} < a_{n} e^{-\frac{1}{12 n}} < a_{n} < a_{1}, \text{ so both sequences have a limit. Since } e^{-\frac{1}{12 n}} \rightarrow 1, \text{ these limits are equal to the same number } a. \text{ Clearly, } a_{n} e^{-\frac{1}{12 n}} < a < a_{n}, \text{ i.e., } a = a_{n} e^{-\frac{\vartheta}{12 n}} \text{ for some } \vartheta \text{ between 0 and 1. Thus, } a = \frac{n! e^{n}}{n^{n+1/2}} e^{-\frac{\vartheta}{12 n}}.

39.9. Prove that the segment $[0,1]$ is equinumerous to the half-interval $[0,1)$.

## 39.4. Countable Sets

A set is called countable if it is equinumerous to the set of natural numbers.
original.solution: 39.9. Let's choose an infinite sequence of pairwise distinct numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \ldots$, strictly between 0 and 1. We will construct a mapping $f:[0,1] \rightarrow[0,1)$ as follows: $f(1)=a_{1}$, $f\left(a_{i}\right)=a_{i+1}$ and $f(x)=x$, if $x$ is different from 1 and from $a_{i}$ for all $i$. It is clear that the mapping $f$ is bijective. Indeed, the inverse mapping $f^{-1}:[0,1) \rightarrow[0,1]$ is constructed as follows: $f^{-1}\left(a_{1}\right)=1, f^{-1}\left(a_{i}\right)=a_{i-1}$ for $i \geqslant 2$ and $f(x)=x$, if $x$ is different from $a_{i}$ for all $i$.

original.problem: 77. Heat Flow. The temperature of three sides of a square metal sheet is maintained at $0^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, while the temperature of the fourth side is maintained at $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. Neglecting heat loss due to radiation, find the temperature at the center of the sheet.
original.solution:
77. If four such sheets are superimposed so that each side has one edge at a temperature of $100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, then the average temperature of each side will be $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}^{\star}$. Therefore, the temperature at the center of the sheet is $25^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$.

$$
\text { [L. Moser, M. M., 24, } 273 \text { (May 1951).] }
$$

Generalizing this method, it can be proven that if the sides of a regular metallic $n$-sided polygon are maintained at temperatures of $t_{i}$ degrees, $i=1,2,3, \ldots, n$, then the temperature at the center of this polygon is $\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} t_{i}$ degrees.

By the definition of the limit:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \forall \varepsilon>0: \exists N(\varepsilon) \in \mathbb{N}: \forall n: n \geq N(\varepsilon):\left|a_{n}-a\right| \\
& \left|\frac{4-4 n+3+4 n}{2(3+4 n)}\right| \\
& \left.\frac{7}{2(3+4 n)} \right\rvert\, \\
& \frac{7}{2(3+4 n)} \\
& 3+4 n>\frac{7}{2 \varepsilon} ;=> \\
& n>\frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{7}{2 \varepsilon}-3\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

It is clear that the limit exists and is equal to $-\frac{1}{2}$.

From $(*)$ it is easy to calculate $N(\varepsilon)$:

$$
N(\varepsilon)=\left[\frac{1}{4}\left(\frac{7}{2 \varepsilon}-3\right)\right]+1=\left[\frac{7}{8 \varepsilon}+\frac{1}{4}\right]=\left[\frac{7+2 \varepsilon}{8 \varepsilon}\right]
$$

original.solution:
## Solution

According to the definition of the limit of a function by Cauchy:

If a function \( f: M \subset \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \) and \( a \in M' \) is a limit point of the set \( M \). A number \( A \in \mathbb{R} \) is called the limit of the function \( f \) as \( x \) approaches \( a (x \rightarrow a) \), if

\[
\forall \varepsilon > 0: \exists \delta(\varepsilon) > 0: \forall x \in M: \quad (0 < |x - a| < \delta(\varepsilon)) \Rightarrow (|f(x) - A| < \varepsilon)
\]

For the given function, we need to show that for any \(\varepsilon > 0\), there exists a \(\delta(\varepsilon) > 0\) such that for all \(x \in M\), the inequality

\[
\left|\frac{3 x^{2} + 17 x - 6}{x + 6} - (-19)\right| < \varepsilon
\]

holds when

\[
|x - (-6)| < \delta(\varepsilon), \text{ where } \delta(\varepsilon) = \frac{\varepsilon}{3}
\]

Thus, as \( x \rightarrow -6 \), the limit of the function exists and is equal to \(-19\), and \(\delta(\varepsilon) = \frac{\varepsilon}{3}\).

## Problem Kuznetsov Limits 8-28

original.solution:
## Solution

According to the definition of the limit of a function by Cauchy:

If a function \( f: M \subset \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \) and \( a \in M' \) is a limit point of the set \( M \). A number \( A \in \mathbb{R} \) is called the limit of the function \( f \) as \( x \) approaches \( a (x \rightarrow a) \), if

\[
\forall \varepsilon > 0: \exists \delta(\varepsilon) > 0: \forall x \in M: \quad (0 < |x - a| < \delta(\varepsilon)) \Rightarrow \left| f(x) - A \right| < \varepsilon
\]

For the given function, we need to show that for any \(\varepsilon > 0\), there exists a \(\delta(\varepsilon) > 0\) such that the inequality

\[
\left| \frac{2x^2 + 5x - 3}{x + 3} - (-7) \right| < \varepsilon
\]

holds for all \( x \) satisfying \( 0 < |x - (-3)| < \delta(\varepsilon) \).

Let's simplify the expression inside the absolute value:

\[
\left| \frac{2x^2 + 5x - 3}{x + 3} + 7 \right| = \left| \frac{2x^2 + 5x - 3 + 7(x + 3)}{x + 3} \right| = \left| \frac{2x^2 + 5x - 3 + 7x + 21}{x + 3} \right| = \left| \frac{2x^2 + 12x + 18}{x + 3} \right|
\]

\[
= \left| \frac{2(x^2 + 6x + 9)}{x + 3} \right| = \left| \frac{2(x + 3)^2}{x + 3} \right| = \left| 2(x + 3) \right| = 2|x + 3|
\]

Thus, the inequality becomes:

\[
2|x + 3| < \varepsilon
\]

This inequality will hold if:

\[
|x + 3| < \frac{\varepsilon}{2}
\]

So, for any \(\varepsilon > 0\), we can choose \(\delta(\varepsilon) = \frac{\varepsilon}{2}\). Therefore, the limit of the function as \( x \rightarrow -3 \) exists and is equal to \(-7\), and \(\delta(\varepsilon) = \frac{\varepsilon}{2}\).

original.solution:
We can assume that the difference $d$ of the progression is positive and not a multiple of 10. Let $d$ be a $k$-digit number.

a) The numbers from A890...0 to A9...9 ($k+2$ nines) all contain nines. There are more than $d$ such numbers. The distance between two consecutive groups of such numbers is $89 \cdot 10^{k} \leq 89 d$. Therefore, the number of terms in the sequence is no more than 90.
b) When transitioning from any term of the sequence to the next, i.e., by adding the number $d$, the $(k+1)$-th digit either remains unchanged or increases by 1 (the digit 9 is forbidden, so the case of changing from 9 to 0 is excluded). If there are no transitions with a change in the $(k+1)$-th digit in the progression, then the number of terms in the progression is no more than 9. Suppose such transitions exist. Since the digit 9 is forbidden, there are no more than 8 such transitions. Between two such transitions, as well as before the first and after the last, there are groups (which may be empty) of transitions without changing the $(k+1)$-th digit. There are a total of 9 such groups.

Consider the term of the progression that stands before a transition that changes the $(k+1)$-th digit. Since it does not contain 9, its $k$-digit "tail" (remainder when divided by $10^{k}$) is no more than $\underbrace{88 \ldots 88}_{k \text{ times}}$. But when adding $d$, a carry must occur. Therefore, $d > \underbrace{11 \ldots 11}_{k \text{ times}}$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_06_d9b26d382f9c77aca61cg-30.jpg?height=60&width=1976&top_left_y=507&top_left_x=41)
The $k$-digit tails themselves form an arithmetic progression with the same difference: $b_{m}, b_{m+1}, \ldots, b_{m+L}$. But $b_{m} \geq 0, b_{m+L}=b_{m}+d L \leq \underbrace{88 \ldots 88}_{k \text{ times}}$, hence $L \leq 7$.

Thus, the total number of terms in the progression is no more than $7 \cdot 9 + 8 + 1 = 72$.

c) An example of the required progression is given by the progression with the first term 1 and difference 125. Its 72nd term is 8876.

original.problem:
Prove that the sequence $x_{\mathrm{n}}=\sin \left(n^{2}\right)$ does not tend to zero as $n$ approaches infinity.

#
original.solution:
Let's use the following trigonometric inequality:

$$
|\sin (\alpha-\beta)| \leq|\sin \alpha|+|\sin \beta| .
$$

Let $\sin \left(k^{2}\right) \rightarrow 0$. Choose $\varepsilonN$. Using the above trigonometric inequality twice, we get:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left|\sin \left((n+1)^{2}-n^{2}\right)\right|=|\sin (2 n+1)| \leq\left|\sin (n+1)^{2}\right|+\left|\sin \left(n^{2}\right)\right|<2 \varepsilon \\
|\sin ((2 n+3)-(2 n+1))|=|\sin (2)| \leq|\sin (2 n+3)|+|\sin (2 n+1)|<2 \varepsilon+2 \varepsilon=4 \varepsilon
\end{gathered}
$$

from which the contradictory inequality follows:

$$
|\sin 2|<4 \varepsilon<4 \cdot \frac{|\sin 2|}{8}=\frac{1}{2}|\sin 2|
$$

(Solution from the book [ [Alperin, Tolpygo])].

## Solution

Consider the maximum of the values of the modulus of the function at the points $0 ; 0.1 ; 0.2 ; \ldots ; 0.9 ; 1$. Let it be achieved at the point $\mathrm{m}=\mathrm{k} / 10$. There are three possible cases: $\mathrm{f}(\mathrm{m})=0, \mathrm{f}(\mathrm{m})>0$ and $\mathrm{f}(\mathrm{m})=\mathrm{f}(\mathrm{m}+0.1)$. Consider the function $\mathrm{g}(\mathrm{x})=\mathrm{f}(\mathrm{x}+0.1)-\mathrm{f}(\mathrm{x})$. It is continuous and $\mathrm{g}(\mathrm{m}-0.1)>=0, \mathrm{~g}(\mathrm{~m})<=0$. By the Intermediate Value Theorem, there exists a number $\mathrm{x}$ lying between $\mathrm{m}-0.1$ and $\mathrm{m}$ such that $\mathrm{g}(\mathrm{x})=0$. We obtain that $\mathrm{f}(\mathrm{x})=\mathrm{f}(\mathrm{x}+0.1)$, and the required number is found.

original.problem:
(Bolzano-Weierstrass) Consider an infinite sequence of real numbers in the interval $[0,1[$ $x_{0}, x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots$.

- Show that either the interval $\left[0, \frac{1}{2}\right[$ or the interval $\left[\frac{1}{2}, 1\right[$ contains an infinite number of elements of the sequence.
- Fix a natural number $n \geq 1$. Show that there exists an integer $k$ in the set $\left\{0,1,2, \ldots, 2^{n}-1\right\}$ such that the interval $\left[\frac{k}{2^{n}}, \frac{k+1}{2^{n}}\right[$ contains an infinite number of elements of the sequence.
original.solution:
- This is a simple application of the pigeonhole principle in the case where we have an infinite number of socks.
- Similarly, it is immediately the pigeonhole principle: our sequence is infinite and the intervals of the form $\left[\frac{k}{2^{n}}, \frac{k+1}{2^{n}}[\right.$ form a partition of $[0,1[$. Then there is one of these intervals that contains an infinite number of terms of the sequence.


## Recurrence

Theorem 2 (Principle of Recurrence).

Recurrence is a fundamental tool for certain proofs.

Consider a mathematical property depending on a parameter $n$. For example, $\mathcal{P}_{n}$: « $\underbrace{1+1+\cdots+1}_{n \text { times }}=n$ ». We want to show this property for all integers $n$. The principle of recurrence indicates that if we can show that the property is true for a certain integer $N$ (often 0, 1, or 2) (initialization phase) and that if $\mathcal{P}_{n}$ is true for a certain integer $n$, then $\mathcal{P}_{n+1}$ is also true (induction step), then the property $\mathcal{P}_{n}$ will be true for all integers $n \geq N$. To keep the same (simple) example:

- Initialization: $1=1$ so $\mathcal{P}_{1}$ is true.
- Induction: Suppose $\mathcal{P}_{n}$ is verified and show that $\mathcal{P}_{n+1}$ is also true.

$$
\underbrace{1+1+\cdots+1+1}_{n+1 \text { times }}=\underbrace{1+1+\cdots+1}_{n \text { times }}+1
$$

By the induction hypothesis, $\underbrace{1+1+\cdots+1}_{n \text { times }}=n$ so $\underbrace{1+1+\cdots+1+1}_{n+1 \text { times }}=n+1$, and $\mathcal{P}_{n+1}$ is verified.

- Conclusion: $\mathcal{P}_{n}$ is then verified for all integers $n \geq 1$.

It may happen that we need to assume the properties $\mathcal{P}_{n}$ and $\mathcal{P}_{n+1}$ to try to show the property $\mathcal{P}_{n+2}$. In this case, we speak of double recurrence. We then need two initializations.

We may also need in some cases that all the properties $\mathcal{P}_{0}, \mathcal{P}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{P}_{n}$ are verified to show the property $\mathcal{P}_{n+1}$. We speak of strong recurrence.
